CONTINENTAL AIRLINES

Tips for Time-Zone Travelers
A service from
CONTINENTAL AIRLINES€

You can't escape
Jet Lag...but
you can control it
Not so long ago, a United States
company executive was having dinner in
Sydney, just after making a trans-Pacific
flight. He dozed off while his client was
talking —and lost the client. That's jet lag.
Can you remember feeling vaguely
"out of it" for a day or two after an overseas
flight? Well, you can chalk this up to the
combined effects of long-distance flight
and vastly different time schedules on
your "body clocks."
This interference with your "body
clocks" causes actual physical changes
to occur. These changes can make you
too tired to stay awake — but too restless
to stay asleep. They can make the food
you eat harder to digest, and the liquor
you drink twice as potent. They can affect
your mood, your judgment, your very
ability to function. This is jet lag... and
every long-distance traveler suffers from it.
The next time you think a long flight
hasn't bothered you, try this simple
test after you get to your hotel: add up a
column of five 3-digit figures. You'll
be surprised at the result —and you'll
become a real believer in jet lag.
In this booklet, we give you some in-
formation on jet lag, plus tips from
leading authorities as well as our own
experience on how best to avoid or
minimize its worst effects.

CONTINENTAL AIRLINES €

10 Minimize
Jet Lag Problems
Plan Your Trip Wisely
• Try to arrive late in the day
• Make a stopover (if crossing 8 or more
time zones)
Adapt Before You Go
Starting 2-3 days before you leave, go to bed
and get up one hour
• LATER (if traveling East to West)
• EARLIER (if traveling West to East)
Stay in Shape While Flying
• Eat lightly
• Drink plenty of fluids
• Avoid (or limit) alcohol
• Exercise

How to Use This Planner
Using the map above, count the time zones you will
cross, including the zone in which your flight originated.
(Example: Going from Los Angeles to Sydney, you will
fly East to West and cross 7 time zones.) Now move the
slide until the number of time zones crossed shows red
in the appropriate circle.
To find your best performance time for each day
after your arrival, refer now to the "Days After Arrival"
column and the adjacent "Peak Performance Times"
window. If you flew East to West, your peak times will be
shown in the "white" column; if you flew West to East,
your peak times will show in the "blue" column. AM
times are printed in light figures; PM times are printed
in bold figures.
Try to allow optimum Jet Lag recovery time. Or, at
very least, get one full night's sleep before you conduct
any important business after a long flight.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Flight information packet issued by Continental Airlines, titled “You can’t escape jet lag... but you can control it”, comprising:a. multipage booklet with color photographic image depicting profile view of aircraft in flight; contains inflight exercise instructions; pocket contains b and c;b. time zone calculator designed to assist travelers with recovery from jet lag; bi-fold format with space for slider (c);c. slider fitting inside b; single-sided card.
